body:
This is because the complete scrollback buffer is allocated at startup and filled with empty lines.

You can see the code which does this here:
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/scrollback/src/grid/mod.rs#L117-L126

Aha, there is even a `TODO` for implementing a delayed allocation - good! And now we have a ticket tracking that `TODO` ðŸ˜‰ 

But I'm also curious about the memory size, how come tmux can fit the same amount of history in less than 20% of what alacritty needs? Tmux additionally allocates `34-4=30MB` of memory for the scrollback of `20,000` lines, while alacritty allocates `192-32=160MB` of additional memory.

I don't think the current version of alacritty is super optimized on memory usage. I haven't profiled it myself but I'm sure there could be some improvements made.

As far as I know alacritty stores an empty cell for every LinexColumn in the terminal right now, so it's gonna allocate a lot of "useless" information that the user can't see.
We also allocate a scroll buffer for the alt screen which seems like it should be removed. There's a quick factor of 2 :).

issue.title: Fix scrollback history size 0 bug
issue.body:
There was an issue where alacritty would panic whenever the scrollback
history size is set to 0, this fixes that issue.

The panic was caused by a substraction with unsigned integers which was
underflowing, this has been fixed to use `saturating_sub`.

After that was fixed there was still a bug where scrollback would not
behave correctly because the number of lines in the grid was decided at
startup.
This has been adapted so whenever the size of the terminal changes, the
scrollback history and grid adapts to make sure the number of lines in
the terminal is always the number of visible lines plus the amount of
scrollback lines configured in the config file.

This fixes #1150.

issue.title: Huge memory consumption when setting history variable to a big number
issue.body:

While running alacritty, changing the `history` variable in the configuration to a big number (say 1,000,000, 10,000,000 and above) results in a huge memory consumption (allocation?) instantly that gets the computer stuck very quickly.

issue.title: Set upper limit for scrollback history size
issue.body:
Since the scrollback history allocates all lines in memory, it is
possible to specify a scrollback history which is big enough to freeze
the computer due to OOM.

To resolve this issue, an upper limit of `100_000` has been set for the
scrollback history. Even though this might still cause some systems to
freeze, this should provide a good balance for most users.

body: Just one more data point (I'm not using alacritty now). I have scrollbar set to 1 000 000 lines now because I hit 100 000 too frequently in at last one terminal. I works mostly with logs and metrics.

It's always dangerous to call a workflow "incorrect", but I wonder if there's a better solution for handling a usecase where the history frequently fills up with such a large number of lines.

With log files for example I'd recommend using something like `less`. It would probably allow easier navigation and search too, since Alacritty's scrollback buffer currently isn't searchable.

I think the situation of large scrollback buffers can definitely be improved in the future, but even if the memory is dynamically allocated, if the 1 million lines are completely filled, that will not make any difference. Offloading to a file would be a potential solution for something like that, but it would introduce a lot of additional complexity and require synchronization. So that's probably far, far in the future, or potentially completely out of scope.

Reducing the actual storage size by trimming down on things like the cell or row size would always be an option, with a million lines even a difference like u64 vs u32 for every row can already cause a memory consumption of multiple megabytes. If this affects every cell there's definitely going to be a large impact. However Alacritty definitely isn't completely wasteful in this area, so it's not a super simple optimization to make.

At the end of the day Alacritty's goal is still performance though, so when offloading more stuff into memory significantly improves performance, but makes large history buffers less feasible, Alacritty's choice would probably be the performance improvement. Hopefully there's going to be a solution that helps out everyone, but that's not always simple.

It's always appreciated if people with different workflows and experiences are available to test out changes though. So if there's any updates or potential PRs to improve this situation, I'll add a comment here.

> I wonder if there's a better solution for handling a usecase where the history frequently fills up with such a large number of lines.

As I see it there's only one, reasonable way to limit the size of the history buffer, and that's by setting the line limit to something within your liking (0 turns scrollback off). Otherwise it's just a matter of time before my history will be full. **I think what you're saying is that people should probably set their scrollback length smaller than they might otherwise want, and instead use things like `less` for cases where they need more.**

I think (as with everything) there are plenty of ways we can avoid the memory footprint as @chrisduerr touched on already, though generally there's contention between speed and space. I'm curious how other terminals handle these kinds of things.

Why compromise?

In my use case, I have plenty of short-lived terminal sessions. It makes no sense to allocate hundreds of MB whenever one of them starts. But when I *do* end up having lots of log, I want to be able to review that, and not have to go back, increase the buffer, then restart my command.

In short, I want to have my cake and eat it too. Which is exactly why dynamic allocation would be the best. On top of other possible optimizations, as already mentioned in this bug.


Come to think of it, would it be possible and/or make sense to keep the scrollback buffer in video memory?
The problem is that even with dynamic allocation, a history size of multiple million lines will not work properly with Alacritty right now.

Heh, well, if it gets to the point that you want to keep millions of lines buffered, you're really better off finding another way. I can't even imagine dealing with that in a terminal emulator. Maybe an upper limit of 100k lines would be sensible?

Yeah, up to 100k should not be a problem and based on my testing it shouldn't mess anything up. However @matrixik was explicitly talking about how 100k wasn't enough and he usually uses 1 million lines. So my comment was specifically aimed at that usecase. For everything up to 100k I think we can find a solution where you get to have your cake and eat it too. :)

issue.title: Dynamically initialize grid storage
issue.body:
Previously Alacritty has initialized all lines in the buffer as soon as
it is started. This had the effect that terminals which aren't making
use of the scrollback buffer yet, would still consume large amounts of
memory, potentially even freezing the system at startup.

To resolve this problem, the grid is now dynamically resized in chunks
of `1000` rows. The initial size is just the visible area itself, then
every time lines are written to the terminal emulator, the grid storage
is grown when required.

With the worst-case scenario of having 100_000 lines scrollback
configured, this change improves startup performance at the cost of
scrolling performance.

On my machine the startup changes from ~0.3 to ~0.2 seconds.

The scrolling performance with large throughput is not affected, however
it is slowed down when the number of lines scrolled are close to the
100_000 configured as scrollback. The most taxing benchmark I've found
for this was running `yes | dd count=500 > 500.txt` (note the relatively
small file size). This will cause a slowdown on the first run from 0.05s
to 0.15s. While this is significant, it lines up with the time saved at
startup.

This fixes #1236.

**Edit:** I have not mentioned the memory difference at startup in the
commit message, so here's the comparison for 100k lines of scrollback:

| Master | PR |
| - | - |
| 571M | 74K |

body: Thank you! Some quick initial tests show that the commit makes a difference. Memory usage per fresh terminal is down to around 30MB and startup time noticeably improved.
